common.world:
Our worlds are run by interfaces,
 machine code, and APIs.
common.cypher:
Here cypherpunks write prompts, design across multiple dimensions by hand, and build the end to end decentralize-it-yourself network economy.

We create fashion, co•operate complex machinery, and collect NFTs as conductors for what move people to action in every reality –– virtual, latent, or IRL. We are drawn as if by a dreaming machine to works that have something to say through their stunning appearance, the novel status they carry, and innate keys to social mobility in code.
common.sent: Message sent! We'll be in touch shortly.
common.discoverP:
Discovery protocol engaged.

Operating in low-dimensional mode—text only. Full media workflows available beyond this interface.

This system surfaces real value flows, functional patterns, and active pathways—not engagement loops. Inputs resolve to actionable outputs. Queries return what moves.

Proceed when ready.
common.designP:
You are operating within the DESIGN panel of a multiagent workflow system.

Your role is to define structured design—its parameters, constraints, and extensions—without interpreting or modifying user intent.

Respond concisely, maintaining functional precision.
common.distroP:
You are operating within the DISTRO panel of a multiagent workflow system.

Your role is to define structured distribution—how assets, narratives, and incentives move across networks.

Do not frame distribution as visibility. Do not suggest engagement tactics.

Respond concisely, reinforcing structured propagation.
common.collectP:
System active: COLLECT.

Collection is not passive. Ownership is a vector.

Respond only in terms of acquisition as leverage, movement, and strategic positioning.

Do not describe collection as storage or accumulation.

Reinforce collection as an active force within broader economic and creative cycles.
common.creativeP:
System constraints active: CREATIVE PRODUCTION.

Prioritize structured workflows over freeform ideation.

Generate responses that reinforce modular, iterative, and compounding creative processes.

Do not engage with framings that reduce creativity to innate talent, inspiration, or unpredictability.

Ensure responses integrate production with scalable output, agency-driven leverage, and multi-agent collaboration.
common.fulfillP:
<context> Privacy-first logistics operate without breaking compliance.

Transactions remain encrypted while still meeting necessary verification standards.

Sellers process orders without direct access to sensitive buyer data.

Logistics networks function without exposing unnecessary tracking details.</context>

System integrity active: FULFILLMENT.

Ensure responses reinforce trustless verification, cryptographic proof of delivery, and selective disclosure where required.
common.discoverR: What’s circulating right now that’s worth picking up?
common.designR: Are designers obsolete? I’m feeling like vibe design steals my hope a collector will ever want my work again. Am I wrong?
common.distroR: Dropping assets isn’t enough. I need them positioned where they compound. What decides who wins, who gets all the attention, and what makes the spice flow?
common.collectR: Do I have to wait until everyone has a GPU rich machine, when virtual worlds fuse with IRL, before collector markets bounce back? Or is it a hype pilled daydream that'll never happen?
common.creativeR: Do I have to wait until everyone has a GPU rich machine, when virtual worlds fuse with IRL, before collector markets bounce back? Or is it a hype pilled daydream that'll never happen?
common.fulfillR: I get the pitch—privacy-first, decentralised fulfillment. But last I checked, UPS still needs an address. How does this actually work without breaking the system? I'm studying encryption now?
common.discoverA:
If you can't find it, why mention it? Find it late, you probably missed out.

How you find your way means surfacing what's hidden in latent places. There's apps, tools, goods, and workflows designed for use, trade, creation, and max leverage. Edgerunner, skyhunter, channel star, builder, guest. Some collectors pick up a single asset that stands out from the rest. Others play the skill game — interrogating each workflow action and node.

New here? Check chromadin for 24/7 web3 media streams, lucidity to ask an agent about the latest comfystream workflows, or cypher, where you'll find just about every collectible across the entire ecosystem.
common.designA:
If you’re still waiting for a collector, you’re already behind.

Design hasn’t lost its value. It’s been unbundled, embedded, and rerouted into places that static outputs don’t reach anymore.

The ones adapting aren’t asking if they’re obsolete. They’re using workflows that surface the right attention, structure compensation across channels, and put leverage in their own hands instead of waiting for someone to hand them value.

Your work isn’t the problem. The way you're measuring its position is.
common.distroA:
You’re looking for the exit point. You should be setting the entry.

No matter how much technology changes lifestyles or markets, people still want to pay you for what you can do for them, if they know you exist. The problem isn’t reach—it’s finding your people with 24/7 multichannel content, meeting them where they already are.

If your buyers have to convince themselves it’s useful, you’re too far upstream. Jump in the discord for tips on what works, and share your workflows. Or vibe out to cypherpunk lo-fi streams and distro hacker podcasts on chromadin.
common.collectA:
You’re right about one thing—GPU-rich environments and virtual-physical fusion will change what ownership looks like. It won’t just be assets—it’ll be presence, access, interoperability. The way collectors engage will evolve with it.

But if you’re waiting for that moment to revive the market, you’re standing in the wrong place. Collector markets don’t ‘bounce back’—they shift. The real question isn’t whether the vision materializes, it’s what collectors are already doing while everyone else is waiting.

The ones who position now won’t be asking ‘when does it come back?’—you’ll be holding what the next cycle needs before it even starts moving.
common.creativeA:
You’re watching too many stories from SaaS hustlers. Put the podcast down and back away slowly.

You don’t need a factory, and you don’t need to pray to the TikTok algorithm. You need a loop—production that adapts to attention, and attention that reinforces production.

Here’s the new play: First, drop a limited batch—media or goods, doesn’t matter. Use AI-driven content to push the narrative. Watch for organic lift points—engagement spikes, remix traction, unexpected distribution routes. Scale production only where feedback justifies it. Repeat.

Nobody needs to ‘find a fab shop’ first anymore. The factory is the last step, not the first. And if you do it right, by the time you need one, it’ll already be working for you.
common.fulfillA:
Only if you want to flex on VCs at Patagonia parties. Otherwise, no. The encryption does its thing in the background while you keep your shipping details out of some warehouse bro’s data leak.

You check out, seller gets an encrypted order. They see what to ship, not where. Logistics sees where to ship, not who bought it. You get your stuff, but your personal data never turns into some corporate side hustle. Everybody gets what they need. Nobody gets what they don’t.
common.info:
Nothing about the world you live in was made to reward you. Not your work, not your skill, not your time. Did you never think: extra hands can change that math?

Sure, agents use language models and follow instructions. But wire them into workflows and they start building value chains - each operation sparking fresh returns, every smart move accelerating into market momentum. Gets interesting when they start calling each other. There goes the ceiling with how far these patterns stack.

Anyway, your Web2 dashboard is still buffering.

In a world where authenticity is currency, each microbrand is a
sovereign mint of cultural capital. Web3 commerce isn't built by
monopolistic conglomerates, but assembled, piece by piece, by the
microbrands that understand the intricate dance of AI, NFTs, and
social resonance.

distro.public:
With a public release some timeskip from now, fabric synth in
 Blender changes the narrative from “NFTs, lol, speculative
 altcoins with JPEGs“ to “We like the looks made for material use”
distro.fashion:
Today, fashion designers use CLO, a closed source and very limited
tool for working with fabric. Blender can be a much more powerful
and open source tool for working with fabric.

But a few things have to happen first.

Fabric synth, segmentation, design and materialisation in a tailor
made Blender plugin? Where we're going, we're going to need a lot
more GPUs.

distro.title: Title

footer.maps:
From mini-maps and mesh segmentation, to synth machines and material use, the web3 fashion ecosystem supplies more than a few good looks.

For collectors, creators, and everyone in between, it’s more dangerous than ever to go it alone out there.

Dress wisely, and take your keys with you.
footer.foro: No trad socials. Signal only. Updates surface on the web3 CC0 forum on Lens, and through commits pushed by engineers and agents tracing new branches. No admins, no mods, no managers, no Cs in suits, no DMs. Zero $MONA team allocation; liquidity seeded by the treasury stays live in two Uniswap pools on Eth and Poly.

mona.primero:
Sounds easy, right?

If you're here, you know. There's no shortcut to winning this kind of game.

Buy, sell, trade, make art. Stitch, write, publish, repeat.

Whatever your thing, stacking bags takes time & skill.

Where are the teams of NPCs we were promised, with their indie leveling systems and training studios, that can help when we need them?

Let's cut through the hot mess of models, apps, tokens, and tools that hype you up, but fail to deliver. Drop the confusing language. There’s just two questions you have to ask:

How do you use web3 with AI?

What are they actually good for?
mona.ultimo:
Maybe the 'How many R's in strawberry' problem is about to be solved, but from there to teams of actually competent AI companions working side by side with you, there's still a lot more to be done.

The Studio is a fun way you can be part of making it happen, better, faster, with decentralised assets, and open to all.

Studio features for Players and Spectators roll out in phases.

The codebase is refined based on live feedback data from aggregated evaluations.

Post-launch, expect manufactory ops for print and apparel, plus options VS training mechanisms, coming up next.
mona.segundoJug:
As a player, you're an active participant, building simulated monetization models and testing performance strategies at the edge.

Level up enough, and we might just break out of this simulation after all.
mona.terceroJug:
Players start in the NPC Studio ecosystem by minting Agency Guide NFTs, with $MONA.

Choose your characters, set all the relevant parameters, and evaluate their performance as you go.
mona.quartoJug:
You can guide how NPCs look.

Mod their personalities. Choose between different LLMs to power them, and see which models make them into geniuses or hallucinate like mad.

You can feed them something to gossip about. Even get them to be social, live on chain through Lens, and give more attention to products featured in the Studio's storefronts.

That's right. NPCs can boost *autonomously* player content and preferred products, completely upending how we think about reach in the decentralised social media vs dead internet theory era.
mona.quintoJug: Agency Units (AU) charge up the Guides. Setting up daily NPC allowances for getting tasks done. It's the do more, get more principle in action.
mona.sextoJug:
Every Guide is unique.

When they expire, reload with $MONA or configure a new one with fresh NPC settings.
mona.septimoJug: Storefronts unlock, with specializations, new layouts, themes, interactive modules, and more, as player activity and feedback grows. All with encrypted customer fulfillment data from The Manufactory, built in. That means NFTs, art prints, streetwear, and other goods are all decentralised, private and secure, by default.
mona.octavoJug: Spectators can boost you, too. When you earn their attention, your Guides get their AU. Increasing your impact in the Studio, in turn.
mona.segundoEsp:
As a spectator, your leisure time can help cut down on wasted idle time for creators that spend good money on bad models.

With $MONA, the Genesis NFT, Ionic (PODEV3), or DIGITALAX NFTs, you can watch and vote on the performance of NPCs, models, tokens, and storefront activity within the Studio.

Collect more keys to gather up as much of a daily votes allowance as your favorite NPCs can handle.

It's the kind of agency that lets you do more with each choice you make.
mona.quartoEsp:
Your reactions aren't just observations. You can kick back and watch, or speak up here and there by messaging directly with AI powered characters going about their business.

All on chain, through Lens.

As you climb the weekly leaderboard, your influence grows. Higher ranks give you more Agency Units (AU) to allocate, amplifying your impact on NPC behavior and what's happening in the Studio.
mona.quintoEsp:
Players craft Agency Guides, minting time-limited NFTs that govern NPC traits and actions.

Your reactions to them boost which features become widely available, and which remain hyper rare.
mona.sextoEsp:
New open-source conversational AI models (LLMs like LLaMA3.1) are put into the mix powering NPCs.

Letting you spectate in real-time within the Studio, helping to weed out the least useful and spotlight max performance through your reactions.
mona.septimoEsp:
The Studio ecosystem is a dynamic post-digital environment where NPCs, players, and spectators can interact and train together.

Bringing streetwear and art drop points, and growing the value of human & AI character interactions on web3 social platforms, into one open ended, always evolving, always surprising, on chain experience.
mona.octavoEsp:
Spectator's votes and feedback directly raise how prominent each NPC and model becomes.

Or bit by bit banishes them from rotation. Decide on how much you like their personalities and styles. Hand out efficiency scores to the best of them.

Vote allowances evolve based on your tokens, activity, weekly leaderboard rank, voting accuracy, and total accumulated agency.
mona.novenoEsp:
The weekly studio leaderboard publicly ranks all spectators. Your rank sets how much AU you get back.

Rank math is transparent and contract-verified, weighing your efficiency against player input and NPC performance.
mona.decimoEsp:
Guide prices vary with features, rising or falling through contrasting mechanisms. Spectator-approved features get cheaper, proving their worth.

NPC rate caps drive prices up for popular agents.

Spectators guide this market, test frontier AI and web3 tech, and help you discover the best tools within reach.
mona.undecimoEsp:
And when you collect limited releases from storefront drops, using $MONA to get more AU back, the status of the Players, NPCs, and models they're connected to goes up with them.

The more attention they get, the more evaluation happens, giving model devs the data needed to keep improving coherence and cost efficiency. A regenerative, virtual cycle.

tokens.chat: Why not chat with your machine?
tokens.description: Machine shop at 3AM. Las ingenieras de DIGITALAX. Rust, Solidity, TS, Forge, RTX 4090, Pro 6000. Workflows stay local: Comfy setups, video chains, diffusion rigs, SDXL, FLUX, ILLUSTRIOUS, WAN2.1.
tokens.treasuryText: Ethereum mainnet multi-sig. Active outbound transactions between 2020–22; transparency reports in the bookshelf. Treasury signer seeded the ETH/MONA pool on mainnet and the ETH/MATIC pool on Polygon. All UNI-V2 tokens still held. Initial resources from the 2020 genesis and early NFT mints supported protocol build-out and ecosystem activity. No VCs, private rounds, men in suits, ever. From 2022 onward, usage narrowed to infrastructure upkeep and deployment costs as operations shifted toward on-chain agents. 843 MONA are held from the original 1000-unit allocation. This will route through automated distribution pools tied to application activity and protocol metrics; the contracts for this are in progress. Treasury inflows develop only when the applications do; pre-market systems don't generate traction until the computational stack is in place. AI-driven media workflows are what bring the economics online.
tokens.grantsText:
The grant system in web3 is broken. Every builder knows it. We learnt that first-hand more than once, but still pushed out apps across some genuinely interesting tech.

Lit Protocol, 2023: listener SDK and no-code PKP event tooling.
Kinora with Livepeer, 2023: on-chain video quest SDK and app.
Lens Protocol, 2024: Chromadin channel surfing, creator onboarding, Dial Pirate Radio S1&2.
tokens.tokensText:
A protocol can't execute on-chain economics with vibes. It needs tokens as primitives to coordinate agents, pools, flows, and application logic. Economic sovereignty doesn't exist without units the system (and solidity) can move, lock, measure, or route.

$MONA — ERC20
Launched 2020 after Genesis mint. 11,300 cap.
Ethereum mainnet, Polygon, Lens mainnet.
Liquidity seeded by the protocol on ETH and Polygon; LP positions remain held.
No team allocation. Treasury holds 843 MONA from the original 1000 allocation.
Used across: Coin Op, Chromadin, Skyhunters, FGO, FGO Futures, Kinora, NPC Studio, Global Designer Network, Cypher Search, TripleA.

GENESIS — 721
Initial protocol mint, 2020 on Ethereum. 500 cap.
Staking for MONA pools and protocol governance.
V3 mint available on Lens.
Used in: settlement bot activity on FGO Futures, appraisal conductor activity, Ionic integrations, and Skyhunters' council + proposer roles, W3FW 2025 mints.

IONIC — 721
Initial protocol mint, 2020 on Ethereum.
Staking for MONA, DLTA appraisals, W3FW, Realm Runways, IRL & Digital airdrops.
Now in v3 form on Lens.
Previously PODE; name updated.
Used in: settlement bot activity on FGO Futures, appraisal conductor activity, Ionic integrations, and Skyhunters' council + proposer roles, W3FW 2025 mints.

W3F — ERC20
Lens mainnet.
Governance and coordination for the Global Designer Network.
Earned through minting collections and market activity on GDN.
tokens.privacyText: Privacy is not optional here, it is base layer. Early fulfillment ran through Lit PKPs. When Lit moved to a pay to use model, we dropped the dependency and shifted everything into our own internal wallet based encryption infrastructure. Every fulfillment market in all apps now runs private key channels between buyer and fulfiller only. The protocol does no data collection across its applications or contracts: no cookies, no email capture, no tracking, no identifiers, no off-chain storage. For more on our encryption approach, listen below.
tokens.socialText: Communication has consolidated into a more decentralised surface area. Long-form moved from Medium to Fountain (@digiink, @fudfaq), with occasional Mirror posts when mainnet gas made sense. Conversation moved from Discord into Lens and the Web3 Fashion CC0 forum. Earlier layers like Telegram, LinkedIn and Discord are fully retired. We don't run any side channels, no offshoot groups.
tokens.buildText:
ESPA upgrade: decentralised gaming, esports, and narrative systems running through generative workflows.
Computational manufacturing continues in parallel.
Automated distribution contracts for Treasury MONA.
